Vita: Dr. Werner Kremer Vita: Dr. Werner Kremer Curriculum vitae: Prof. Dr. Werner Kremer Institute of Biophysics and Physical Biochemistry, University of Regensburg, Universitätsstraße 31 93053 Regensburg, Germany phone: ++49-941-943-2185 fax : ++49-941-943-2479 email: werner.kremer@ur.de Personal Prof. Dr. rer.-nat., Dipl.-Physiker, german, married, 2 children. Born June 22nd 1961, Neusustrum, Germany. Cofounder and consultant of LipoFIT Analytics GmbH, spin-off at the University of Regensburg ( www.lipofit.de , now www.numares.com ) Education 2003 Habilitation and Venia legendi in biophysics, University of Regensburg, Germany. 1992 Ph. D. (Dr. rer.-nat.), physics, University of Göttingen, Germany. 1989-1992 Ph.D. thesis work at EMBL outstation, Grenoble, France. 1984-1987 Diploma thesis in Physics at University of Göttingen, Germany. 1980-1987 Study of Physics, University of Göttingen, Germany. . Affiliation Since 2010: Appointment as professor (apl.) in Biophysics, Institute of Biophysics and Physical Biochemistry, University of Regensburg, Germany. Since 1997: Staff member and Lecturer, Institute of Biophysics and Physical Biochemistry, University of Regensburg, Germany. 1993 - 1996: Visiting Scientist/Postdoc, Department of Chemistry and Structural Biology Division at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, USA. 1989 - 1992: Research Associate, EMBL outstation, Grenoble, France. Further activities: Since 2011 Member, Editorial Board (Section Editor), BMC Biophysics. Qualificatons: Chemistry and Physics Plasma lipoprotein and metabolic profiling by NMR spectroscopy to investigate the metabolic profiles and pathophysiology of disease development and progression, application of high pressure NMR spectroscopy to study the physico-chemical properties of proteins including the stabilization of folding intermediates (disease-causing isoforms) involved in neurodegeneration; multidimensional NMR spectroscopy of DNA, peptides and proteins, including 3D and 4D methods using 15 N and/or 13 C heteronuclei including 2 H decoupling (also protonless NMR spectroscopy with Bruker Cryoprobe TCI technology); 31 P and 19 F NMR spectroscopy to study folding and dynamics of proteins; dynamic laser light scattering (DLS and depolarized DLS) for characterization of DNA and proteins; cavity perturbation technique in the microwave range for characterization of conductors and semiconductors; low temperature techniques down to 4 Kelvin. Computer Programming experience with fortran-77, C, C++, Python, perl, Java, micropower pascal, basic, assembler; experience in use of all Microsoft-Dos (IBM-PC) and Macintosh systems, Linux, Silicon Graphics and Sun workstations (UNIX), Felix, Aurelia, Auremol, NMRPipe, InsightII, Discover, Xplor, CNS, Dyana, Molmol and various bioinformatics software packages. Molecular biology and biochemistry Project leader (BIO1, safety class 1 GMO, and BIO2, safety class 2 for pathogenic GMO); metabolic profiling of cell cultures and body fluids; p urification of plasmid DNA, DNA fragments, and peptides and proteins with chromatography (FPLC, HPLC, BioCad-, Äkta-, Hewlett-Packard-, Waters- and Beckman systems); polymerase chain reaction (PCR); subcloning, sequencing and overproduction of plasmid DNA in fermenters; overexpression of uniformly isotopically labeled recombinant proteins in E. coli , and protein biochemistry (purification, refolding, improvement of solution conditions). Teaching Lecture Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy in cooperation with Prof. D.E. Wemmer at the University of California, Berkeley, USA. Lectures biophysics I and II in cooperation with Prof. Dr. Dr. H.R. Kalbitzer. Course content included structural methods in molecular biophysics: NMR spectroscopy, X-ray crystallography, electron microscopy, atomic force microscopy, small angle scattering, dynamic light scattering, and fluorescence spectroscopy. Supervision of the biophysical seminar series ?Modern methods of structure determination?. Weekly introductory lectures on experimental physics for medical science students on basic physics with special emphasis on medical aspects. Seminar series on imaging techniques such as MRI, CT (X-ray, PET/SPECT), fluorescence and ultrasound. Weekly introductory lectures on experimental physics for biochemistry and biology students on basic physics with special emphasis on biological aspects. Weekly introductory lectures on experimental physics for students of chemistry (LA GY Mathe/Chemie, Biologie/Chemie) on basic physics with special emphasis on biological aspects. Supervision of a practical course in basic physics for students of medicine. Development of a practical course in basic NMR spectroscopy, including the corresponding script. Supervision of this course for biochemistry and biology students. Supervision of 1-2 summer students in each term. Typical duration for each is 4-6 weeks. Supervision of 4 Ph.D. students in the areas ?Metabonomics and lipidomics monitored by NMR spectroscopy?, ?Protein structure determination using multidimensional and multi-nuclear NMR spectroscopy?, ?High pressure NMR for the characterization of the folding of proteins? and ? 31 P-NMR spectroscopy for the characterization of conformational transitions in GTP binding proteins?. Presentation of past achievements My past achievements resulted from key challenges during my career. These include academic, scientific and business achievements. Academic achievements: I assisted in the establishment of a new biophysics department under the leadership of Prof. Dr. Dr. Hans Robert Kalbitzer. This includes the organization of the construction work for the biochemistry and molecular biology laboratories, the technical setup of the NMR facility with 4 spectrometers (800 MHz, 600 MHz, 500 MHz, and 300 MHz), and the organization and setup of a computer room. In addition I developed new practical hands-on courses for students and practical trainees. For this I digitized the introductory lectures on experimental physics for life science students. I focused on basic physics with a special emphasis on life sciences. This includes a seminar series on imaging techniques of MRI, CT covering X-Ray, PET and SPECT, as well as fluorescence and ultrasound. Every semester 200 life science students have to pass the practical training of basic physical experiments. Scientific achievements: The biophysics department of Regensburg is nowadays known as a center for the cutting-edge research on NMR spectroscopy of biomolecules under high hydrostatic pressure. This is very important in regard to the high number of organisms living in the deep sea and to understand the deep sea biology on the molecular level. In collaboration with colleagues from the Archaeenzentrum (Prof. Stetter and Prof. Thomm) we were able to study proteins of extremophiles and to understand molecular origins of stability to harsh conditions. Internationally recognized our laboratory has cooperations with laboratories in the US, France, UK and Japan which resulted in a core to core project ( http://www.biologie.uni-regensburg.de/Biophysik/Kalbitzer/c2c/index.html ). As another initiative I founded together with colleagues the Center for Magnetic Resonance in Chemistry and Biomedicine (CMRCB) ( http://www.uni-regensburg.de/forschung/zentrum-magnetische-resonanz/ ). Together with Prof. Dr. Dr. Hans Robert Kalbitzer I was able to locally organize two nationwide recognized meetings in the field of NMR spectroscopy (GDCh FG NMR meeting in 2000 with Italy as a partner country and in 2008 with the partner countries Austria and Switzerland). Business achievements: As a spin-off from our biophysics department I founded together with my colleagues Dr. Fritz Huber and Prof. Dr. Dr. Hans Robert Kalbitzer the company LipoFIT Analytics GmbH ( http://www.lipofit.de/index_engl.html ). LipoFIT has currently the opportunity to initiate a paradigm shift in the field of diagnostics and become a market leader in NMR-based analytics. Since November 2012 LipoFIT Analytics GmbH has changed to Numares Group GmbH ( http://www.numares-group.com ).

Vita: Dr. Werner Kremer Vita: Dr. Werner Kremer Curriculum vitae: Prof. Dr. Werner Kremer Institute of Biophysics and Physical Biochemistry, University of Regensburg, Universitätsstraße 31 93053 Regensburg, Germany phone: ++49-941-943-2185 fax : ++49-941-943-2479 email: werner.kremer@ur.de Personal Prof. Dr. rer.-nat., Dipl.-Physiker, german, married, 2 children. Born June 22nd 1961, Neusustrum, Germany. Cofounder and consultant of LipoFIT Analytics GmbH, spin-off at the University of Regensburg ( www.lipofit.de , now www.numares.com ) Education 2003 Habilitation and Venia legendi in biophysics, University of Regensburg, Germany. 1992 Ph. D. (Dr. rer.-nat.), physics, University of Göttingen, Germany. 1989-1992 Ph.D. thesis work at EMBL outstation, Grenoble, France. 1984-1987 Diploma thesis in Physics at University of Göttingen, Germany. 1980-1987 Study of Physics, University of Göttingen, Germany. . Affiliation Since 2010: Appointment as professor (apl.) in Biophysics, Institute of Biophysics and Physical Biochemistry, University of Regensburg, Germany. Since 1997: Staff member and Lecturer, Institute of Biophysics and Physical Biochemistry, University of Regensburg, Germany. 1993 - 1996: Visiting Scientist/Postdoc, Department of Chemistry and Structural Biology Division at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, USA. 1989 - 1992: Research Associate, EMBL outstation, Grenoble, France. Further activities: Since 2011 Member, Editorial Board (Section Editor), BMC Biophysics. Qualificatons: Chemistry and Physics Plasma lipoprotein and metabolic profiling by NMR spectroscopy to investigate the metabolic profiles and pathophysiology of disease development and progression, application of high pressure NMR spectroscopy to study the physico-chemical properties of proteins including the stabilization of folding intermediates (disease-causing isoforms) involved in neurodegeneration; multidimensional NMR spectroscopy of DNA, peptides and proteins, including 3D and 4D methods using 15 N and/or 13 C heteronuclei including 2 H decoupling (also protonless NMR spectroscopy with Bruker Cryoprobe TCI technology); 31 P and 19 F NMR spectroscopy to study folding and dynamics of proteins; dynamic laser light scattering (DLS and depolarized DLS) for characterization of DNA and proteins; cavity perturbation technique in the microwave range for characterization of conductors and semiconductors; low temperature techniques down to 4 Kelvin. Computer Programming experience with fortran-77, C, C++, Python, perl, Java, micropower pascal, basic, assembler; experience in use of all Microsoft-Dos (IBM-PC) and Macintosh systems, Linux, Silicon Graphics and Sun workstations (UNIX), Felix, Aurelia, Auremol, NMRPipe, InsightII, Discover, Xplor, CNS, Dyana, Molmol and various bioinformatics software packages. Molecular biology and biochemistry Project leader (BIO1, safety class 1 GMO, and BIO2, safety class 2 for pathogenic GMO); metabolic profiling of cell cultures and body fluids; p urification of plasmid DNA, DNA fragments, and peptides and proteins with chromatography (FPLC, HPLC, BioCad-, Äkta-, Hewlett-Packard-, Waters- and Beckman systems); polymerase chain reaction (PCR); subcloning, sequencing and overproduction of plasmid DNA in fermenters; overexpression of uniformly isotopically labeled recombinant proteins in E. coli , and protein biochemistry (purification, refolding, improvement of solution conditions). Teaching Lecture Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy in cooperation with Prof. D.E. Wemmer at the University of California, Berkeley, USA. Lectures biophysics I and II in cooperation with Prof. Dr. Dr. H.R. Kalbitzer. Course content included structural methods in molecular biophysics: NMR spectroscopy, X-ray crystallography, electron microscopy, atomic force microscopy, small angle scattering, dynamic light scattering, and fluorescence spectroscopy. Supervision of the biophysical seminar series ?Modern methods of structure determination?. Weekly introductory lectures on experimental physics for medical science students on basic physics with special emphasis on medical aspects. Seminar series on imaging techniques such as MRI, CT (X-ray, PET/SPECT), fluorescence and ultrasound. Weekly introductory lectures on experimental physics for biochemistry and biology students on basic physics with special emphasis on biological aspects. Weekly introductory lectures on experimental physics for students of chemistry (LA GY Mathe/Chemie, Biologie/Chemie) on basic physics with special emphasis on biological aspects. Supervision of a practical course in basic physics for students of medicine. Development of a practical course in basic NMR spectroscopy, including the corresponding script. Supervision of this course for biochemistry and biology students. Supervision of 1-2 summer students in each term. Typical duration for each is 4-6 weeks. Supervision of 4 Ph.D. students in the areas ?Metabonomics and lipidomics monitored by NMR spectroscopy?, ?Protein structure determination using multidimensional and multi-nuclear NMR spectroscopy?, ?High pressure NMR for the characterization of the folding of proteins? and ? 31 P-NMR spectroscopy for the characterization of conformational transitions in GTP binding proteins?. Presentation of past achievements My past achievements resulted from key challenges during my career. These include academic, scientific and business achievements. Academic achievements: I assisted in the establishment of a new biophysics department under the leadership of Prof. Dr. Dr. Hans Robert Kalbitzer. This includes the organization of the construction work for the biochemistry and molecular biology laboratories, the technical setup of the NMR facility with 4 spectrometers (800 MHz, 600 MHz, 500 MHz, and 300 MHz), and the organization and setup of a computer room. In addition I developed new practical hands-on courses for students and practical trainees. For this I digitized the introductory lectures on experimental physics for life science students. I focused on basic physics with a special emphasis on life sciences. This includes a seminar series on imaging techniques of MRI, CT covering X-Ray, PET and SPECT, as well as fluorescence and ultrasound. Every semester 200 life science students have to pass the practical training of basic physical experiments. Scientific achievements: The biophysics department of Regensburg is nowadays known as a center for the cutting-edge research on NMR spectroscopy of biomolecules under high hydrostatic pressure. This is very important in regard to the high number of organisms living in the deep sea and to understand the deep sea biology on the molecular level. In collaboration with colleagues from the Archaeenzentrum (Prof. Stetter and Prof. Thomm) we were able to study proteins of extremophiles and to understand molecular origins of stability to harsh conditions. Internationally recognized our laboratory has cooperations with laboratories in the US, France, UK and Japan which resulted in a core to core project ( http://www.biologie.uni-regensburg.de/Biophysik/Kalbitzer/c2c/index.html ). As another initiative I founded together with colleagues the Center for Magnetic Resonance in Chemistry and Biomedicine (CMRCB) ( http://www.uni-regensburg.de/forschung/zentrum-magnetische-resonanz/ ). Together with Prof. Dr. Dr. Hans Robert Kalbitzer I was able to locally organize two nationwide recognized meetings in the field of NMR spectroscopy (GDCh FG NMR meeting in 2000 with Italy as a partner country and in 2008 with the partner countries Austria and Switzerland). Business achievements: As a spin-off from our biophysics department I founded together with my colleagues Dr. Fritz Huber and Prof. Dr. Dr. Hans Robert Kalbitzer the company LipoFIT Analytics GmbH ( http://www.lipofit.de/index_engl.html ). LipoFIT has currently the opportunity to initiate a paradigm shift in the field of diagnostics and become a market leader in NMR-based analytics. Since November 2012 LipoFIT Analytics GmbH has changed to Numares Group GmbH ( http://www.numares-group.com ).

Prof. Dr. Christine Ziegler Prof. Dr. Christine Ziegler Dr. Chitra Rajendran Group leader Dr. Kristian Parey Project leader Project: Structural and functional characterization of archaeal membrane proteins

Prof. Dr. Christine Ziegler Prof. Dr. Christine Ziegler Dr. Chitra Rajendran Group leader Dr. Kristian Parey Project leader Project: Structural and functional characterization of archaeal membrane proteins

Prof. Dr. Christine Ziegler Prof. Dr. Christine Ziegler Structural and functional characterization of archaeal membrane proteins Structural characterization of the mechanosensitive channel of small conductance MscCG from C. glutamicum Structural Investigations of the Stressosome Complex Structural and functional characterization of eukaryotic osmolyte transporters Structural investigation of S-layers from Pyrobaculum aerophilum Structural and functional characterization of archaeal membrane proteins Our research focus on the structural characterization of all membrane proteins in the host-symbiont system Ignicoccus hospitalis-Nanoarchaeum equitans, which are suggested as putative archaeal ancestor of mitochondria. Here, our group is working in close collaboration with the Archaea Centre and the group of Harald Huber. Ignicoccus hospitalis is an anaerobic obligate chemolithoautotrophic Crenarcheaon that exhibits beside other highly unusual features an exceptional cell compartment formation, which is characteristic for eukaryotes. Two membranes are forming an intermembrane compartment (IMC) of a variable width of 20 to 1000 nm filled with membrane vesicles. The energized ?outer cellular membrane? (OCM) comprises an ATPase and a H2:sulfur oxidoreductase complex. Moreover, pore complexes of 7 and 24 nm, respectively, were observed in electron micrographs (2). By crystallizing and functionally characterizing proteins located in either of the two membranes and in the vesicles we want to learn about the evolution of eukaryotic transport and protein translocation systems. In our group we clone, express and crystallize proteins originated from these different membranes to gain insights into their composition, distribution, and function. The final goal will be to understand the unique role of I. hospitalis and its symbiont Nanoarchaeum equitans as putative archaeal host system in the evolution of mitochondria. References: 1. H. Huber et al., (2012) The unusual cell biology of the hyperthermophilic Crenarchaeon Ignicoccus hospitalis. Antonie Van Leeuwenhoek, 102(2), 203-219. 2. T. Burghardt et al., (2007) The dominating outer membrane protein of the hyperthermophilic Archaeum Ignicoccus hospitalis: a novel pore-forming complex. Mol Microbiol. 2007, 63(1), 166-76. Crystals of a membrane bound complex of Ignicoccus hospitalis Localization of membrane proteins in Ignicoccus hospitalis Structural characterization of the mechanosensitive channel of small conductance MscCG from C. glutamicum Prokaryotic mechanosensitive channels (MS) play a major role in the cellular protection system under hypo-osmotic stress situations. The membrane protein MscCG from Corynebacterium glutamicum was previously described as a mechanosensitive channel of small conductance. These MS-channels act as emergency valves upon sudden osmotic downshift when excessive water inflow increases the turgor pressure. They sense the increased membrane tension and get activated within milliseconds to release compatible solutes to the environment and prevent the cell from lysis. Recently, MscCG was shown to be involved in the glutamate efflux of C. glutamicum under glutamate production conditions like the cell- growth under biotin limitation or the treatment with penicillin. Interestingly, MscCG was also reported to function under hyper-osmotic stress conditions - in fine-tuning the steady-state concentration of the compatible solute betaine in the cell. MscCG from C. glutamicum (533 aa) exhibits 23% sequence identity to the MscS-channel (mechanosensitive channel of small conductance) from E. coli (286 aa), which forms a functional homoheptamer. The most similarities between MscCG and MscS are in the N-terminal part (see homology model) which represents the channel domain. Furthermore MscCG contains a long C-terminal domain exhibiting a unique sequence. This C-terminal part was recently shown to carry an additional transmembrane domain. Therefore our group is interested in the structural differences of MscCG to other MscS-channels and we want to learn more about the so far unknown C-terminal domain of MscCG. References MscCG: 1. Ruffert et al., (1999) Identification of mechanosensitive ion channels in the cytoplasmic membrane of Corynebacterium glutamicum. J Bacteriol, 181, 1673-1676. 2. Nakamura et al., (2007) Mutations of the Corynebacterium glutamicum NCgl1221 gene, encoding a mechanosensitive channel homolog, induce L-glutamic acid production. Appl Environ Microbiol, 73, 4491-4498. 3. Bass et al., (2002) Crystal structure of Escherichia coli MscS, a voltage-modulated and mechanosensitive channel. Science, 298, 1582-1587. 4. Börngen et al., (2010) The properties and contribution of the Corynebacterium glutamicum MscS variant to fine-tuning of osmotic adaption. Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, 1798, 2141-2149. 5. M. Becker, et al., (2013) Glutamate efflux mediated by Corynebacterium glutamicum MscCG, Escherichia coli MscS, and their derivatives. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.bbamem.2013.01.001 Homology model. The monomeric structure model of the truncated MscCG?247 (blue) in comparison to the E.coli MscS-monomer structure (2oau)(yellow). Structural Investigations of the Stressosome Complex Bacteria have almost permanently to deal with conditions which provide physical stress. Thus it is essential for bacterial cells to be able to detect and counteract a wide range of environmental stress such as heat, salt, toxins, UV-light and ethanol. One adaption to such circumstances is the general stress response (GSR) of Bacillus subtilis that permits the activation of the sigB factor which binds the RNA polymerase for transcription of 150 general stress genes to protect the cell. This GSR in B. subtilis is mediated by a 1.8 MDa cytoplasmic stressosome complex - the key signaling system which is composed of multiple copies of three different proteins (RsR, RsbS and RsbT). Due to the fact that in representatives of most bacterial phyla gene clusters which encode for stressosome homologs are present, this concept of a stressosome complex is presumably more often distributed among bacteria. The stressosome itself plays therefore an important role in many different kinds of environmental stress regulations. Up to now it is not known how different stress signals are detected and mediated by the stressosome. Our research is focused on the stressosome complex. Therefore we express and purify the protein complex and investigate the stressosome via electron microscopy (A) and 3D reconstruction (B). A: EM negative stain B: few class-sums (program EMAN2) Structural and functional characterization of eukaryotic osmolyte transporters Secondary transporters play important roles in maintaining vital functions in the mammalian kidney, which constantly encounters major changes in osmolality during urinary concentration. The renal hydration state is adjusted by accumulation of several osmolytes, one of which is betaine. Betaine-mediated volume regulation prevents severe dysfunction of the kidney and the central nervous system. Moreover, betaine counteracts the destabilizing action of urea on protein structures in renal cells. Renal betaine uptake is facilitated by BGT-1 (GAT2, gene name SLC6A12), which belongs to the osmolyte branch of the human NSS or Solute Carrier 6 (SLC6) family. Besides kidneys, BGT-1 is found in the brain and in the liver mediating also the transport of the neurotransmitter GABA. Both betaine and GABA transport is chloride-dependent and coupled to the transport of 3 sodium ions. During hypertonicity, BGT-1 transcription and insertion to the basolateral plasma membranes is increased and transport of betaine is up-regulated. However, the molecular mechanism of sensing hypertonicity and subsequent regulatory membrane insertion of BGT-1 is unknown. Controlled folding by N-glycosylation might be one regulatory mechanism, as the interaction with N-glycans affects targeting and functional insertion to the plasma membrane in many different proteins. Structural investigation of S-layers from Pyrobaculum aerophilum Surface (S)-layers form the outermost cell compartment of many bacteria and archaea. They consist of monomolecular arrays of protein or glycoprotein species, maintain structural rigidity and protect the organism from environmental elements. Their 2D crystalline lattice shows either an oblique, tetragonal or hexagonal symmetry the latter being predominantly found in archaea. In our group we focus on structural investigation of S-layers from archaea using electron microscopy, especially electron crystallography and electron tomography.

Prof. Dr. Christine Ziegler Prof. Dr. Christine Ziegler Structural and functional characterization of archaeal membrane proteins Structural characterization of the mechanosensitive channel of small conductance MscCG from C. glutamicum Structural Investigations of the Stressosome Complex Structural and functional characterization of eukaryotic osmolyte transporters Structural investigation of S-layers from Pyrobaculum aerophilum Structural and functional characterization of archaeal membrane proteins Our research focus on the structural characterization of all membrane proteins in the host-symbiont system Ignicoccus hospitalis-Nanoarchaeum equitans, which are suggested as putative archaeal ancestor of mitochondria. Here, our group is working in close collaboration with the Archaea Centre and the group of Harald Huber. Ignicoccus hospitalis is an anaerobic obligate chemolithoautotrophic Crenarcheaon that exhibits beside other highly unusual features an exceptional cell compartment formation, which is characteristic for eukaryotes. Two membranes are forming an intermembrane compartment (IMC) of a variable width of 20 to 1000 nm filled with membrane vesicles. The energized ?outer cellular membrane? (OCM) comprises an ATPase and a H2:sulfur oxidoreductase complex. Moreover, pore complexes of 7 and 24 nm, respectively, were observed in electron micrographs (2). By crystallizing and functionally characterizing proteins located in either of the two membranes and in the vesicles we want to learn about the evolution of eukaryotic transport and protein translocation systems. In our group we clone, express and crystallize proteins originated from these different membranes to gain insights into their composition, distribution, and function. The final goal will be to understand the unique role of I. hospitalis and its symbiont Nanoarchaeum equitans as putative archaeal host system in the evolution of mitochondria. References: 1. H. Huber et al., (2012) The unusual cell biology of the hyperthermophilic Crenarchaeon Ignicoccus hospitalis. Antonie Van Leeuwenhoek, 102(2), 203-219. 2. T. Burghardt et al., (2007) The dominating outer membrane protein of the hyperthermophilic Archaeum Ignicoccus hospitalis: a novel pore-forming complex. Mol Microbiol. 2007, 63(1), 166-76. Crystals of a membrane bound complex of Ignicoccus hospitalis Localization of membrane proteins in Ignicoccus hospitalis Structural characterization of the mechanosensitive channel of small conductance MscCG from C. glutamicum Prokaryotic mechanosensitive channels (MS) play a major role in the cellular protection system under hypo-osmotic stress situations. The membrane protein MscCG from Corynebacterium glutamicum was previously described as a mechanosensitive channel of small conductance. These MS-channels act as emergency valves upon sudden osmotic downshift when excessive water inflow increases the turgor pressure. They sense the increased membrane tension and get activated within milliseconds to release compatible solutes to the environment and prevent the cell from lysis. Recently, MscCG was shown to be involved in the glutamate efflux of C. glutamicum under glutamate production conditions like the cell- growth under biotin limitation or the treatment with penicillin. Interestingly, MscCG was also reported to function under hyper-osmotic stress conditions - in fine-tuning the steady-state concentration of the compatible solute betaine in the cell. MscCG from C. glutamicum (533 aa) exhibits 23% sequence identity to the MscS-channel (mechanosensitive channel of small conductance) from E. coli (286 aa), which forms a functional homoheptamer. The most similarities between MscCG and MscS are in the N-terminal part (see homology model) which represents the channel domain. Furthermore MscCG contains a long C-terminal domain exhibiting a unique sequence. This C-terminal part was recently shown to carry an additional transmembrane domain. Therefore our group is interested in the structural differences of MscCG to other MscS-channels and we want to learn more about the so far unknown C-terminal domain of MscCG. References MscCG: 1. Ruffert et al., (1999) Identification of mechanosensitive ion channels in the cytoplasmic membrane of Corynebacterium glutamicum. J Bacteriol, 181, 1673-1676. 2. Nakamura et al., (2007) Mutations of the Corynebacterium glutamicum NCgl1221 gene, encoding a mechanosensitive channel homolog, induce L-glutamic acid production. Appl Environ Microbiol, 73, 4491-4498. 3. Bass et al., (2002) Crystal structure of Escherichia coli MscS, a voltage-modulated and mechanosensitive channel. Science, 298, 1582-1587. 4. Börngen et al., (2010) The properties and contribution of the Corynebacterium glutamicum MscS variant to fine-tuning of osmotic adaption. Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, 1798, 2141-2149. 5. M. Becker, et al., (2013) Glutamate efflux mediated by Corynebacterium glutamicum MscCG, Escherichia coli MscS, and their derivatives. Biochim. Biophys. Acta, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.bbamem.2013.01.001 Homology model. The monomeric structure model of the truncated MscCG?247 (blue) in comparison to the E.coli MscS-monomer structure (2oau)(yellow). Universität Regensburg - Botanik Universität Regensburg - Botanik Forschung Arbeitsgruppe Besl Pilze im Raum Regensburg Durch das Zusammentreffen verschiedener geologischer Verhältnisse zeigen die Pilze im Regensburger Raum eine hohe Biodiversität. Deren aktueller Stand wird in zahlreichen Einzelbeiträgen erfasst. Mitarbeit am Datenbankprojekt "BayFlora Kryptogamen" Sepedonium und andere mykophile Pilze Die auf Pilzfruchtkörpern parasitierenden Pilze werden hinsichtlich Systematik, Inhaltsstoffe und Wirtswahl untersucht. Ein Schwerpunkt ist dabei die auf Boletales spezialisierte Gattung Sepedonium, eine der Nebenfruchtformen von Hypomyces (Ascomycetes). Hinweis für Studierende Aus allen drei oben genannten Arbeitsgebieten können Themen für Examensarbeiten vergeben werden.

Universität Regensburg - Botanik Universität Regensburg - Botanik Lehre Arbeitsgruppe Besl Lehrveranstaltungen im Sommersemester Übungen zur Biodiversität III (Pilze) Inhalt: Frischpilze werden gemeinsam in der Regensburger Umgebung gesammelt und mit Hilfe von umfangreicher Literatur bestimmt. Die Veranstaltung liefert einen Eindruck der Formenfülle innerhalb der einheimischen Pilzflora und vermittelt Kenntnisse über Systematik, Ökologie und Toxikologie dieser Organismen. Auch praktische Aspekte wie Speisewert und Verwechslungsgefahren werden angesprochen. Zeit und Ort: Jeweils als 7tägige Blockveranstaltung in der zweiten Septemberhälfte (genaue Daten nach Vereinbarung); Kursraum V (Bio 10.22) Kryptogamenexkursion für Fortgeschrittene Exkursion Betreuer: Dr. Helmut Besl O. Dürhammer M. Reimann Voraussetzung: Vorherige erfolgreiche Teilnahme am Moos-, Flechten- oder Pilzkurs. Inhalt: Diese 5- bis 7-tägigen Exkursionen finden im Rahmen des Projekts "BayFlora Kryptogamen" statt. Von einem Standort in Bayern aus werden täglich Exkursionen durchgeführt, bei denen Moose, Flechten und Pilze gesammelt werden. In Arbeitsgruppen werden die Funde jeweils anschließend identifiziert und so ein Beitrag zur Kenntnis der Verbreitung dieser Organismen geleistet. Die Teilnehmer erhalten einen Überblick über die Kryptogamen des Exkursionsgebiets sowie über die Arbeit mit Karten und Datenbanken. Zeit: Meist Mitte September Exkursionen zur Kenntnis der heimischen Pflanzenwelt Exkursion Zusammen mit weiteren Mitgliedern des Lehrstuhls Inhalt: Während des Sommersemesters finden jeweils mittwochs etwa 3stündige Exkursionen in der Umgebung Regensburgs statt. Dabei werden für Interessierte aller Semester die heimische Flora und Vegetation näher unter die Lupe genommen. Soweit vorhanden, werden zusätzlich auch Pilze, Flechten und Moose besprochen. Zeit und Ort: Jeweils mittwochs, 17.00 Uhr; Treffpunkt entsprechend Aushang Biologisches Praktikum (Teil II/Botanik) (für Lehramt an Grund-, Haupt- und Realschulen; entspricht gleichzeitig dem Botanischen Praktikum für Geographen) Betreuer: Dr. Helmut Besl E. Loos Inhalt: An Hand ausgewählter Organismen wird in Vorlesung und Kurs ein Überblick über die Entwicklungsgeschichte der Pflanzen gegeben. Neben den Algen, Moosen, Farnen und Blütenpflanzen werden auch die Cyanobakterien und Pilze (incl. Flechten) kurz behandelt. Besondere Beachtung finden dabei Bau, Lebensweise und Fortpflanzung. Zeit und Ort: Mo, Di, Do, Fr. 8.15-12 Uhr (zweite Semesterhälfte); H 42 bzw. Kursraum II (Biol. 40.04) Lehrveranstaltungen im Wintersemester Großpraktikum zur Evolutionsbiologie der Pflanzen 54 690 Botanisches Großpraktikum I, Pflanzenstämme 12 st. Inhalt: An Hand ausgewählter Organismen wird ein Überblick über die Entwicklungsgeschichte der Pflanzen gegeben. Neben den Algen, Moosen, Farnen und Blütenpflanzen werden auch die Cyanobakterien und Pilze (incl. Flechten) kurz behandelt. Schwerpunkte stellen dabei die Höherentwicklungen in den Bereichen der vegetativen und sexuellen Organe dar. Zeit und Ort: Als 5-wöchiger Block im Jan./Feb.; Kursraum V (Bio 10.22)
